div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, APRIL 18, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Scakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor,(for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK.
div.p: Subiorlbad Capital £ 1.500,000 Paid up ,| .. 600.000 Rasarva Fund ,, 600,000 Tho Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Limited, undertake very description of banking business on tho most favourable conditions. Current accounta opened with commercial houses and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankoru. Fixed deposits for ono year certain received at 3 per cent, por annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to bo agreed upon. Letters of credit for the use of travellers are issued payablo in all parts of the World. Approved bills discounted. Bills, documentary invoices, etc., collected. Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable al over tho World. Foreign exchange bought and sold. Advances mado upon approved securities and upon cotton, ootton-sood, sugar and other merchandise. The purchase and salo of stocks aflci shares on the London Stock Exchange ;and on the looal and Continental Bourses, undertaken. Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safo custody in the Bank’s fire-proof strongl rooms, and the Bank will attend to tho collection of tho coupons and drawn bonds so deposited as they full due. Mercantile credits issued. Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected. All further particulars and information can be obtained on application. The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers.

div.head: The Education Bill
div.p: The Bishop of London, in a letter condeming the Education Bill yesterday, annonnces the summoning of a mass meeting in the Albert Hall for the 11th May, which is to be the first of a series dealing with the question which ii naturally absorbing so much attention at home, While many of the detail* of Mr. Birrell’a scheme most necessarily remain obscure until the text of the Bill is printed, the main principle emerge* without possibility of oontradiction. The old voluntary schools, which since the Act of 1902 have been referred to in state documents as "non-provided,” are to be swept away. After January 1, 1908, no public elementary school will be allowed to receive * peony of public money, either from rates or taxes, if it does not abandon its character and become a “provided” school within the meaning of the Act. That is to say, managers appointed by the local Education authority are to be substituted for the existing boards on which the clergy are represented ; there is to be no inquiry into the religions beliefs of the head teachers, and, with a certain exception to be mentioned immediately, no distinctive religions teaching in the shape of Catechistn or formulary is to be imparted within the schools. Where, however, the local authority can come to terms with the owners of an existing “noty provided ’ school, the following arrangement may be made. From Monday to Friday during the boon between nine and tour these schools are to belong absolutely to the local authority, their used during Saturday and 8nnday, and in the evenings, being reserved to the owners. And “facilities” ate to be provided by the local education authority for special denominational teaching in these schools, by enabling children whose parents desire it to receive such teaching lor half an boar on two mornings in the week, presumably during school hours. Sock teaching is to be provided at the expense of the parent, and the school teachers are expressly prohibited film giving it. By a further provision, which is obviously and almost avowedly intended to “square” the Roman Catholic, > public inquiry may be held in the oaae it any transferred voluntary sshool in an urban ares, and where funr-fifths of the parents desire that the exiating denominational education may be continued, “facilities for religions instruction of a special character," as it is euphemistically expressed, may be provided. Snob, to put it as briefly and teohnically as possible, is the scheme by which the Church oi England is to be robbed of her schools and her clergy driven ignominiocsly not of the buildings for the very existence of which they and their predecessors are to largely responsible. When it is remembered that more than half the children in public elementary schools at the present moment an being educated in “non-provided” schools, the extent of the revolution may be imagined. As the "Globe” says, a blow is being dealt at the Church, only comparable with its foimtl disestablishment. Not the slightest recognition ia made of the sacrificed by which past generations of Chnrohmen have provided ont rif their own pooketa for the neglect and the shortcomings of the State. No allowance is made for the millions which have been raised by Churchmen for elementary education since 1171, when the State first took up its obligations. Even since 19G2 the sums expended by tbs friends of voluntary schools in order to- compete with the exacting requirements of unfriendly educational authorities have amounted to a very considerable figure. In ths urban areas it is possible that the “fonr- fifths” olaose may not aot exclusively in favour of the Roman Catholios. The demand for dogmatio teaohing is not oonfined to Homan Catholic parents, and if the public inquiry is conducted with any semblanoe of fairness, we shall be surprised if "extended opportunities for denominational teaohing” have not to be sopplied to Church of England echools, whose tendenoy is of the type moBt abhorrent to Dr. Clifford and Mr. Hollowell. But, as would inevitably happen in the parallel oase of diaestablisbment, it is the ratal districts which will suffer most f recent inquiries in many dioceses have shown that there are numbers of village sohools where not merely fonr-fifths but bine-tenths of the parents desire the continuance of the existing religions instruction. There is to be one law, however, for the children of town parente, smother for the children of rural parente.One contingency has apparently been overlooked by the promoter of the Bill- There are plenty of parithre in rnral England qnite wealthy enough to refose to snrrend?r the sshool buildings, and to continue to work them on their present basis. What will Mr. Birrell do t hen t

div.p: The Brindisi Mail. The mail from Barope, via Brindisi and Port Said, will be distributed at the G. P. 0., Alexandria, at 4.45 p.m. to day.

A. S. C. A walking stick which was found on the A. S. C. grounds at the Shem el Neasim meeting may be had on application at the cilices of the “Gazette.” Death from Intoxication. A Sudanese in an advanced state of intoxication was found in a street in the Menshieh quarter yesterday and removed to hospital, but expired on the way. A Bride of Three Weeks. It is said that H. H. Prince Kamel Paoha bas divorced his second wife, Princess Fatimah Hanem, widow of the late Manshawi Pacha, whom he married three weeks ago. Business Notice. M. Emmanuel C. Zervudachi and M. Nicolas C. Zervadachi have been authorised to sign on behalf of the firm of C. Q. Zervudachi & fils, in conjunction with M. Ambroise C. Zetvndaohi and M. Georges C. Zervudachi. "Trade Mark.” Such is the title of a new publication in French which emanates from the publishing works of Messrs. Lagoudakis, Alexandria, and whose aim is to promote the interest* of the holders of trade-marks registered in Egypt. German Church at Cairo. An offer has been made for the purchase of the German church and school at Cairo. The site is 3,400 metres in extent and the amount offered is £119,000. A committee has been appointed to consider whether the offer should be entertained. Charitas. The Ernesto Rossi dramatic club are giving a special performance of Emile Zola’s Tkerise Raquin at the Zizinia Theatre to-morrow, in aid of the victims of the Courribres catastrophe. The performance is under the patronage oi Baron Acton and M. Pierre Girard. Alhambra Theatre. This evening, the Egyptian trio of young female mandolinists, who have been trained by Mr. A. Thompson, will make their debut at this theatre. The programme to-night will consist of European music. Another concert of Arab music will be given to-morrow. New House of Rest. Residents in Alexandria and Rimleh are invited to attend the laying of the foundation stone of “Fairhaven,” a house of rest for missionaries by the sea, by the Right Rev. Bishop Morley, D. D., Archdeacon of Egypt, to-day at 4.30 p. m. The site is three minute walk from Palais Station, on the brow of the hill southwards. San Stefano Flower Show. We are requested to state that the Railway Administration has kindly offered to allow members of the Khedivial Horticultural Society and native exhibitors who intend visiting the Flower 8how next Saturday to travel at half fares from Cairo. The tickets will be available from Thursday to Monday but certificates must be obtained from Dr. Keatings before starting. New 8chool for Alexandria. The Erwat El Woska Benevolent Society of Alexandria has purchased a portion of the former residence of the late Hassan Pacha Rassim at Ras-el-Tin, belonging to M. Escoffier, manager of the Credit Lyonnais at Alexandria, for the purpose of converting it into a sshool. The price of the property, amounting to L.E. 4,000, has been paid by M. Zervudaobi, who will reseive the amount from the society in instalments of LE. 400 per annum, charging no interest Flor de Dindigul Cigars In Egypt The sale of this famous brand of cigars has reached enormous figures, not only in nearly all parts of the world (including Great Britain), but has caught on amongst discriminating smokers throughout the whole of Egypt, on account of its mildness, delicacy, delightful fragrance, and nutty aroma. Its merits have gained for it 12 gold medals, including the gold medal at the Cape Town exhibition. Any of our readers who have not tried Flor de Dindigul cigars can obtain them at most dealers throughout Egypt. The fact that the Flor de Dindigul cigar bas gained & larger sale than any other branded cigar in the world is a testimony which shows its sterling worth. British Chamber of Commerce. We are requested to draw the attention of manufacturers and merchants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt. The Chamber was formed in 1896 with the sole objcot of assisting British trade in this country, and its services are always at the disposal of members desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appointing suitable agents. As no fees are charged for suoh advice, it is, we think, in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered a twelve months’ subscription—commencing from any date - is merely the nominal sum °f£l. We may also mention that members receive post free a copy of the monthly journal issued by the Chamber. Further particulars 'nay be obtained from the secretary : 6, Rue do l’Ancienne Bourse, Alexandria, the hon. secretary in Cairo, Mr. W. E. Kingsford, 8haria Cherifein, or from our London office, 36, New Broad street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

div.head: DEATH OF EMIR MAHMOUD
div.p: HIS CAPTURE AND CAPTIVITY. The death of the. Emir Mabmond, whose funneral took place yesterday at Damietta, will recall to oar readers the history of the battle of Om Debrikat, better known as the battle of the Atbara, which took place on the 8th April, 1898. Mahmoud, who commanded the Dervish forces, was taken prisoner on this occasion and after being led in triumph through the streets of Berber was sent down to Wady Haifa, where he wa9 interned for two and a half years. He was then sent to Damietta, where he remained a State prisoner in an honourable captivity till his death. The deceased Emir, before his defeat and capture, accomplished several notable feats of arms, his last success being the captare of Metemmeb, then held by the Jaalin, who had revolted against the Khalifa after the capture of Abou Hamed by the Egyptian forces. Of the Emir Mahmoud the late G. W. Steevens wrote in his admirable sketch of the campaign “With Kitohener to Khartonm” Now to see what we had done and suffered. And first, for a new fillip to exaltation, Msh- mond was a prisoner. Some soldiers of the 10th Sudanese had found him as they swept through the zariba—found him sitting on his carpet, his weapons at his side, after the manner of defeated war chiefs who await death. He was not killed, and presently he was brought bareheaded before the Sirdar—a tall, dark brown complexioned man of something between thirty and forty. He wore loose drawers and a gibba —the dervish uniform which still mimics the patched shirt of the Mahdi, but embroiders it with gold. His face was of the narrow-cheeked, high-foreheaded type, for he is a pore-bred Arab : his expression was cruel, but high. He looked neither to right nor to left, but strode op to the Sirdar with his head erect “Are yon the man Mabmond ?” asked the Sirdar. , “Yes ; I am Mahmoud, and I am the same as you.” He meant commander-in-chief. ‘ Why did you come to make war here 1” “I came because I was told, - the same as you.” Mahmoud was removed in custody ; but everybody liked him the better for looking at his fate so straight and defiantly. Bat small leisure had anybody to pity Mabmond : the pity was all wanted for our own people. Describing the triumphal entry of the Sirdar into Fort Atbara, with Mahmond a prisoner, Mr. Steevens says ...Farther behind, in a dear space, came one man alone, his hands tied behind his back. Mahmoud ! Mahmoud, holding his head up and swinging his thighs in a swaggering stride—but Mahmoud a prisoner, beaten, powerless. When the people of Berber saw that, they were convinced. It was not a lie, then : the white men had conquered indeed. And many a dark skinned woman pressed forward to call Mahmond ‘ Dog” to his face: it was Mahmond, last year, who massacred the Jaalin at Metemmeb.

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: Yesterday there were seven cases of plague and eight deaths in hospital at Deshna and one case at Samalont. 10 cases were under treatment. Nine oases and seven deaths are reported to-day. Sir Horace Pinching reports to the Minister of the Interior:- During the week ending on April 15, 1906, 35 oases of plagae occurred in the whole of Egypt, distributed as follows: 2 at Awlad Amron (Keneh Markaz and Province),' 16 at Deshna (.Keneh), 13 at Mankatein (Sa- malont Makaz. Minieh), 3 at Tantah (Ghar- bleb), 1 at Wasta(Beni-8ooef),the victim being a person who had come from Mansonrab. Though the number of cases in the whole of Egypt is not alarming, isolated oases and deaths suspected to be caused by plague are reported in various districts and it is consequently very necessary to limit the movements of individuals from one district to another and their aggregation in large numbers as far. as is humanly possible. For this reason I have suggested to your Excellency that the celebration of the Motiled el Nebi should be limited to one night instead of the usual seven, and that this feast should be localised as far as possible and the admission thereto of strangers in any locality avoided. From January 1 to April 15, 1906, 63 oases of plague were reported, against 40 in the for responding period of last year.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN DEBT
div.p: The Egyptian Debt Office (Administration de la Dette Publique d’Egypte) has just i published its annual report for the year 1905, which is the thirtieth year of its administration. As particular interest attaches to this year’s figures, which show for the first time the result of the new financial arrangement legalised by the Degree of the Khedive, dated 28th November, 1934, we give below the main I features of the report, in anticipation of Lord Cromer’s usual yearly statement. It will be remembered that the above Decree, in conformity with the desires of the European Powers, substituted the gross receipts of the land taxes as the guarantee for the interest service of the Debt, the old guarantee consisting of the provincial tributes ! and the railway and telegraph receipts, etc. The substitution is now proved to be thoroughly justified. On the 28th November, 1904, the revenue raised by the old system of taxation amounted to L.E. 4,200,000 per annum, while the service of the Debt, including the expenses of its administration, required a sum of dose upon L E. 3,600,000. There existed also, and of course still exists, a reserve land of L.E. 750,003, to assure the service of the three sections of the Debt—the Guaranteed, the Privileged and the Unified—in the order of priority named, and on the possible absorption of this sum the general resources of the Treasury were to be called into requisition. It now appears from the report that the reserve fond of L.E.750,000 is still intact The revenues of the thirteen provinces of Garbieh. Menonfieh, Behera, Galionbieh, Daka- lieb, Charkieh, Ghizeh, Beuisouef, Fayoum, Minieh, Asaioat, Ghirgeh and Assouan (the province of Keneh alone was set apart by the Decree to guarantee the Domain Loan) amount to L.E.3,648,000, to which must be added L.E.87,000 for interest on investments and L.Kl,ot)0 for taxes due but not collected—in all, L.E.3,636,000. On the other side of the account are Interest service; Guaranteed 3 per Cent Debt L.E. 307,000 ; Privileged 3} per Cent. Debt, L.E. 1,062,000 ; Unified Debt L.E.2,183,000 ; expenses of administration, L.E. 36,000; total, L E. 3,688,000. The credit balance available for the Treasury is consequently L.E. 48,000. It also appears from the report that L.E. 129,400 of the Guaranteed Debt was amortised daring 1905 and L.K 42,700 during the first two months of the present year ; so that on the 1st ultimo the Guaranteed Debt stood at L.E. 7,805,700. The Privileged at the same date was L.E. 31,127,780, and the Unified Debt LE, 55,971,960, so that at the present moment the total amount of the Egyptian Debt may be stated approximately at L.E. 94,905,000, requiring an interest service of some L.E. 3,552,000 annually, which, as seen above, is well covered by the land tax.

div.head: HELIOPOLIS OASIS COMPANY
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the George Nungovich Hotels Company, Limited, was held yesterday afternoon for the purpose of deciding on the issue of nine thousand five hundred (9,500) ordinary shares at the rate of £12 per share. Rostowitz Bey, chairman of the board of directors, opened the meeting with an interesting speech in which he reviewed the flourishing condition of the company and mentioned that the object of the new issue was to cover the expenses of the purchase of Mena House Hotel and the new buildings for the Savoy Hotel on the two new plots of land recently purchased. The shareholders present, who represented a total of eighteen thousand shares, agreed to the proposed issue unanimously.

div.head: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI, LTD.
div.p: Mr. Constantine Meimarachi, chairman of Walker and Meimarachi, Limited, has returned to Cairo after having visited Vienna, Berlin, London; Paris, and Brussels for the purpose of inspecting the stores in these capitals in order to form a model for the mammoth establishment which his company intend erecting on the new site they have purchased in the Ismailia quarter of Cairo. Of all the stores in the capitals of Europe which he visited he was chiefly impressed with the establishment of Harrod’s in London, which he deoclares has no equal elsewhere, and he intends to establish Walker and Meimarachi’s new stores at. Cairo on the model of Harrod’s. The services of Messrs. Frederick Sage and Company, the well-known shop-fitters of London, have been engaged for the new building.

div.head: A NOVELTY FOR CAIRO
LATEST TELEPHONE DEVELOPEMENT
div.p: Egypt is advancing so rapidly and day by day is being endowed with the latest products of European invention, that we are not surprised to learn that Cairo is soon to see the installation of one of the latest and most wonderful inventions known in Europe. For some years past Buda-Pesth has had a curious development of the telephone known as the “Speaking Gazette.” This is a development of the theatrophone and the tape news machine, which have been in vogue for some years in London and Paris and other European Capitals. Most of the houses of the well-to-do inhabitants of Buda-Pesth are fitted with a telephone instrument, which tells its hearers all the news of the world all the day through, beginning in the morning and ending late at night with the last strains of the operas that are being given. A well-known Hungarian has been in Cairo for some months organising the installation of a similar system of vocal newspapers in the capital of Egypt The patents have already been registered at the Mixed Tribunals and a petition for the grant of a concession has open made to the Egyptian Government. This system of a simultaneous telephone for news will be worked in the following manner. A central office in Cairo will distribute the news by means of a special microphonic apparatus installed at the house of every subscriber. The machine will give vent to the local news of Egypt and the chief events that are taking place throughout the whole world. The latest Stock Exchange quotations, market reports, and all the most interesting intelligence of every sort and kind will be offered by this machine at regular intervals. At certain times of the day the machine will note the exact astronomic time and from hour to hour personal and social news items, reports of the latest fashions, the fullest details of the latest crimes, religious news, Court intelligence, hotel information, shipping items, arrivals of mails, and, in a word, every possible item of information that can interest anybody Will be repeated by this machine in the many and various languages spoken in Egypt. This will obviously be a very surprising addition to the amenities of life in Cairo. Besides acting as a transmitter of news, the machine will be an educational force, for it will report scientific and literary lectures, will tell stories for the children, and will impart instruction in foreign languages. The central station at Cairo will, it is hoped, be in direct communication with the Khedivial Opera House and the theatres, so that subscribers may hear everything at their own homes, and whenever a concert or other entertainment is given a full vocal reproduction will ensue. Every subscriber will receive each month a programme of the time when the various classes of news are to be transmitted so that they need not be worried to have to listen to matters for which they have no taste. The utility of such an invention is indisputable and few families at Bada-Pesth but subscribe to the “Speaking Gazette.” The invention is also of extreme utility for blind and illiterate people and affords a pleasant alleviation to the invalid. It is expected that before the end of the year Cairo will be fitted with a complete installation of “Speaking Gazette” machines.

div.head: WIRELESS TELEGRAPH IN EGYPT
div.p: The Legislative Council met yesterday to consider the Government project with regard to the monopoly of wireless telegraphy in Egypt, but no decision was arrived at and the sitting was postponed till the 25th in«t. The council, however, decided to request an official of the Ministry of Public Works to attend the next meeting.

div.head: THE ULEMA STRIKE
div.p: The ulema of Alexandria, who went out on strike lately, have made the three following demands: to be exempt from the duty of taking care of the talaba (scholars) after lessons, to be granted the certificate of ulemaship, and to have a council of administration analogous to that of Al-Azhar. The first condition was granted, but the consideration of the second and third was postponed! The ulema have resumed work in compliance with the commands of H. H. the Khedive. In compliance with the -request of the Alexandria Ulema board, the board of Al-Azhar University has appointed Sheikh Yonssef ihadili, Sheikh AH Idrees, Sheikh Abd el ffajeed el-Lebbao, and Sheikh Mohamed el- Dunyari, nlema of Al-Azhar, as teachers to the Ulema board of our city, with pay at the rate of LE. 8 a month. The new teachers arrived here on Monday.

div.head: THE GORDON COLLEGE
THE COURSES IN THE TRAINING COLLEGE
div.p: The Training College at Khartoum has two sides, an Education side and a Law side. On the former students are trained to act as teachers of all subjects except English in the higher elementary schools of the department; The object of the Law side is to secure qualified officials to fill posts in the Mohamedan Courts. It is hoped that the teachers will eventually become headmasters or inspectors, and the Law students eventually Cadis. All instruction is in Arabia Ultimately all will be expected before entrance to have passed through one of the elementary vernacular schools, and also to have spent Borne years listening to the lectures given in mosques and khalwes by men of re- organized learning and authority. Hitherto it has been easier to find candidates who have fulfilled the second of these conditions, but every year marks progress : in 1905 six of the new entrances—about 25 %—came from the elementary schools at Berber, Rafaa, and Suakin, as compared with two only from Rafaa in 1904. For three years after entrance all the students work together irrespective of their final destination, the subjects taught being religion and law, Arabic language and literature, history and geography, arithmetic, geometry, algebra, and drawing. ' Students who have completed their third year to the satisfaction of the examiners are then distributed between the two sides, but even after this all continue to work together at the above-mentioned subjects for 21 hours out of the 83. The remainder of the week is devoted partly to these general subjects with which deeper acquaintance is desirable in the future professions of the students. The Law students, besides studying the methods of procedure in Mohamedan Courts, receive farther instruction in the principles of administration and law as obtained in both the civil and religions courts of the country. The education side meanwhile studies the theory and practice of teaching (the theory being at present reduced to a minimum, and the practice consisting chiefly of model and criticism lessons) and, in addition, those secular subjects which will be useful to them hereafter. The College has now been in existence for over four years and numbers 102; who are distributed among tne different classses thus : first year 30, second year 27, third year 21. fourth year, Education side 7, Law side 7, fifth year, Education side 5, Law side 5.

div.head: K. OF K. AND THE EGYPTIAN ARMY
div.p: A long communication on “Lord Kitchener and the Indian Army” from the “Times” special correspondent in India appears in the unusual form of a letter to the editor, and embodies a grave indictment of the methods of the Indian Commander-in-Chief. He concludes his criticism of Lord Kitchener with the following reference to events in Egypt:— The great success achieved largely by Lord Kitchener’s unquestionedability in the reconquest of the Sudan was very nearly wrecked not long afterwards in a disaster due to the same defects of which many people dread the consequences in India. Only a short time before Lord Kitchener was ordered to South Africa, an incipient mutiny amongst the native troops in the Sudan, which arose out of his disregard in peace time for pecnliar idiosyncrasies that he had actively ignored so long as the excitement of active service lasted, was only detected and suppressed at the eleventh hour. The suppression of Lord Cromer’s "opinion" on Lord Kitchener’s scheme is easily explained when one remembers that he alone combined with an intimate knowledge of the Indian aspects of the question a still more intimate knowledge of the defects of Lord Kitchener’s qualities.” “I am fully conscious,” adds the writer, "of my responsibility in making these grave statements.”

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Cairo season may be said to have ended with the garden party given by Dean and Mrs. Butcher yesterday at all Saints’ Vicarage. The British colony was very largely represented, and all who hid the pleasure to be present agreed that the season could not have terminated more pleasantly.
The Hon. and" Mrs. A. E. Guineas arrived at Alexandria on Monday by the Schteswig in order to join their yacht Fantome.

The many friends of Dr. Clarke,' professor at the Polytecbnic School, Ghizeh, will be glad to hear that he has been elected vice-president of the 1st and 2nd sections of the French Association. Farther, the October Bulletin of the association contains two papers contributed by him, viz., (1) “A General Theory of Abacs of Alignment of every order” ; (1). “A Fundamental Theorem in disc rim i nates applicable to differential equations.” Aa most of the contributions read at the meetings of the French Association are given in its bulletins merely in the form of brief resumes, the publication in full of these two papers is a high compliment to their author. Our hearty congratulations.
We are glad to see from the "London Gazette” that the Rev. F. B. N. Norman-Lee, C.F.,has been promoted chaplain to the forces, first class.

Naonm Bey Shoucair, of the Intelligence Department, has been transferred to the Archives Department of the Sudan Government. Our readers are doubtless aware that Naonm Bey Shouoair is the author of an excellent Arabic history of the Sudan from the earliest times to its reconquest.

A marriage has been arranged, and will take pl*oe in Teddington (Middlesex) early in May. between Mr. Robert L Naville. of the Imperial Ottoman Bank, Cairo, eldest son of Mr. E. A. Naville, of Geneva, and Miss Dorothea Dudley Ward, second daughter of the late Mr. Thomas Dudley Ward.

The marriage of Me. Zaki Ibrahim to Virginie, daughter of Spiro Bey and Mme Spiro, will take place on the afternoon of the 22nd inst. at the residence of the bridegroom’s parents in Champs Elyades-road, Moharrem Bey.
Nungovioh Bey, who is leaving Alexandria on Friday next for Athens for the Olympic Games, will return to Cairo in about a fortnight.

Durban, April 17. The Zuzuland chiefs Siganandi and Ndubi, in the vicinity of the Nkbandla forest, have refused tco-operate against Bambaata. Reinforcements are being despatched and the Militia is remobilising. The situation is disquieting. (Remtifj

London, April 17. It is expected that the Russian loan will be issued next week. The bulk of the proceeds will probably be allowed to remain in the various monetary centres concerned ; hence gold withdrawals are unlikely. French holders of 1901 bonds will have a preferential allotment. (ReuUr) St. Petersburg, April 17. (Official). The Russian loan amounts to £99,5000,000 at 5 % ; price about 89. Twenty million are to be issued in Russia, 48 million in France, 13 million in Great Britain, and the rest in Austria and Holland. „ (Reuter) St. Petersburg, April 17. Russian Liberals have started a movement, in opposition to the issue of the loan, before the Duma meets, on the ground that it makes the autocracy independent of the Duma and would be likely to lead to fresh repression.

Rome, April 17. The Italian press is considerably mollified by the Emperor William’s condolences. (JR.) Berlin, April 17. The ' Tageblatt,” commenting on the outcry causad by the Emperor William’s telegram, warns Italy of her dependence on Germany’s support, adding that the Germans are determined to take the lead in Central Europe, (ft.)

div.head: KING ALFONSO'S MARRIAGE
div.p: Madrid, April 17. King Alfonso is taking most valuable presents to Cowes, including a set of splendid jewels. Great preparations are being made here for the marriage : the festivities will include a review and bullfights. (Reuter) Cowes, April 17. King Alfonso has arrived here. (Reuter)

div.head: APPOINTMENT FOR HERR WEDEL
div.p: The “Norddeutsche Zeitung” announces the nomination of Count Bernstorf as Consul General for Germany in Egypt. Herr Wedel has been appointed second secretary to the Embassy at Rome. (Havat) Berlin, April 17. The "Norddentscbe Allgmeine Zeitung” states that Count Georg von Wedel, of the German Legation in Cairo, has been appointed second secretary in Rome. (Reuter)

div.head: THE EDUCATION BILL
div.p: London, April 17 The Bishop of London, in a letter condemning the Education Bill, anounnces the summoning of a mass meeting in the Albert Hall on the 11th May, the first of a series. (Reuter)

div.head: ROYAL VISIT TO ATHENS
div.p: Corfu, April 17. The King and Queen of England and the Prince and Princes*~of Wales have left for Athens. (Reuter) Athens, April 17. King Edward has arrived. He received a veritable ovation. (Havat)

div.head: PORTUGESE NAVAL MUTINY
div.p: Lisbon, April 17. Owing to the mutiny, the ships of the Portuguese quadron have been distributed in the various harbours along the coast. (R )

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID
EFFORTS AT EXTERMINATION
div.p: (From our Correspondent.) Port Said, April J3 The Mosquito Conference held here, as far as the numbers of the audience and their appreciation of the lecturer, Dr. Piessant, went, was an unqualified success. The clever doctor's treatment of his subject was punctuated from time to time by applause, and the vote of thanks was most enthusiastically given. Should our energetic and capable sanitary inspector, who has already made great strides in cleaning up the town, also succeed in clearing out the mosquito, he will win the thanks of all residents and passengers. As the sum required is not one beyond the resources of the town, there should not be much difficulty in obtaining it. The many people, who have already tried the methods advocated for dealing with these insects, speak highly of the results. Now that the conscience of the town has been aroused to the necessity of dealing with the subject, and it has been pointed out that co incident with the disappearance of the mosquito there is reason to believe that the weekly visitation of the sanitary officials will assist in correcting other evils, probably the dangers of plague and other nuisances will be removed. Should Port Said succeed even half as well as lsmailia a great nuisance will have been mitigated. When the wholesale destruction of mosquitoes commences great interest will be taken in the result It behaves all and sundry to give their assistance, financial or otherwise, in such a work. Thus the progress of the town will be one not only of stones and mortar, but also of progressive sanitation, leading up, possibly, eventually to the entire removal of the sites where the mosquitoes breed, the natural corollary being the introduction of a cheaper and more modern method of sewage disposal. Russian Transports. Russian transports come through the Canal almost every day now. Most of these ships pass in voluntary quarantine as it is difficult otherwise to keep the men from obtaining vodka. The men are fine, strapping fellows, and as far as physique goes, are in striking contrast to the less bulky Japs. The Persia. Considerable disappointment was caused to people desirous of leaving or visiting the Persia by some suspicions oases of illness having caused the authorities to make the ship pass through in quarantine. We were pleased to bear that there were no further oases in the least suspicious—that as a matter of fact there were no patients at all in hospital after leaving Suez. Entente Cordiale. The new French Consul, ML/ Meyrier, has taken up his duties at Port Said. It has been suggested that some attempt should be made to bring the Preach and English people more together. After the Mosquito Conference it was mooted that to raise funds a Universelle Entente Cordials be held at which children of different nations might form a procession and join in sports and games whilst their elders enjoyed some music. The Late Governor. As evidencing the interest taken in the town by the late Governor, it is noteworthy that he presided at the two public meetings in the El Dorado the day previous to his departure. He has always lent a strong support to the formation of the International Sporting Club, the ground of which is now completed. Under his chairmanship a committee was appointed from the founders and ordinary members. This committee was representative of all nationalities. -(Die subscription for ordinary members is 100 P.T. Mr. Chessman is secretary.

div.head: TWO BEAUTIFUL WOMEN WHO ESCAPED SPRING CATARRH BY TAKING PE-RU-NA
Spring Fever is Spring Catarrh-Nothing Robs One of Strength Like Spring Catarrh.
div.p: Mias B. Inez SilverA, 189 W. lS6th street. New York City, Grand Recorder Dang liters of American Independence, writes: “Nine years of work, without a vacation, wore out my nervous system. I lost my appetite and felt weak and exhausted nearly all the time. “Peruna restored me to perfect health In five week*. It la the finest tonic for a weary woman that / know of. / gladly endorse It. ”~B. Inez Silvern.
Peruna is the most prompt and permanent cure for all cases of nervous prostration caused by systemic catarrh known to the medical profession.

Mias Estelle Campbell, HO N. High street, Nashville, Tenn., writes: "Peruna helped me whenalmoot everything else tailed. I was rundown from overwork, as I had not been able to take a vacation for three years and naturally my nerves were all unstrung and I was greatly In need of rest and n tonic. “I went away for two months, but did not seem to get my strength back, although I was taking a prescription which the doctor gave me before I went away. “At the request of my relatives, with whom I was visiting, I began to use Peruna, and you cannot realize how glad I was when within a week I found I was feeling so much better. Inside of a month I was feeling splendidly, ready and able to take up my work again."—Estelle Campbell.

A Sprint Tonic. Almost everybody needs a tonic In the spring. Something to brace the nerves, Invigor,ate the brain, and cleanse tho blood. That Peruna will do this Is beyond all question. We have on file, thousands of letters which testify to the curative and preventive value of Pernna In cases of nervons depression and rnn down conditions of the system. We qnote a typical case: Mr. Prank Williams, 8935 84th street. div.head: EASTER SERVICES
div.p: ALL SAINTS’ CHURCH, CAIRO. The Easter services at All Saints’ Church, Cairo, were numerously attended. The Holy Communion was celebrated four times, at 6.30 а. m., 7.30 a.m., 8.30 a.m., and after morning service. The number of communicants at the four celebrations was 286. The services were conducted by Very Rev Dean Butcher D. D., Rev. Professor Sayce, Rev. H.U. Weitbrecht, Pb. D, Rev. Thompson Burns, M. A., and Rev. G. II. Rankinge. The Dean took his text from Luke 16.31. “If they hear not Moses and the Prophets neither will they be persuaded though one rose from the dead.” The musical part of the service was directed by Mr. Serle Peacock and a very efficient choir. The hymns were 131, 134, and 499 in the morning, and at evensong 135, 125 and 140. The church was decorated with palms, iris, arums, white and red lilies and white roses. ST. MARK’S CHURCH, ALEXANDRIA. The attendance at all the services on Easter Day at the above church must be a source of gratification to the Chaplain. At the 7.30 service the chapel was too small to hold all the communicants and the attendance at the 8 o'clock and midday services far exceeded that of last year, amounting to 141. At the 11 o’olock service every seat was taken including the extra chairs placed in the aisle. The choir acquitted themselves with great credit, the rendering of the psalms both morning and evening being bright and were given with excellent precision. “Break forth into joy” (J. Barnby) TeDeum and Jubilate (Tours in F) were well sung and showed great care. The offertory sentences, "Let your light so shine” and “Lay not up for yourselves,” by Vine Hall, were given, and we hope the choir will repeat them at no distant date. At the choral celebration Baptise Calkins’ Communion service in B flat was sung, and at the dose of the morning and evening services the choir and congregation sang “God save the King." The collections for the Poor Fund at St. Mark’s at 7.30 a.m. and 8 a.m. amounted to P.T. 622. The collections at 11 a.m. and at б. 15 p.m., which were presented as an Easter offering to the assistant chaplains, amounted to P.T. 4105 2/10. Last year the Easter Offering was P.T. 1727 5/10. The church was beautifully decorated, the font, pulpit, lectern, choir stalls, and the altar vases meriting special mention. Those responsible for the decorations were Mmes. Eyre, Roberts, Steinschneider, Ward, Misses Dodd, Barwell, Batcheller, Morrison, and Talbot. Among those who sent flowers were the following: Mmes. Callendar, Crafton, Cornish, Foster, Diokaon, Rowden, W.T. Smith, Pioton, S. H. Carver, P. W. Carver, Moss, Misses Batcheller and Coates, and Mr. Ebell. Want of space prevents us from giving an account of the services at All Saints,’ Ramleh. HOME INTERNATIONAL. THIRD LIST OF DONATIONS. Schuler, Maganas Victoria, Messrs. Orosdi Back, Abaskela, Messrs. Davies Bryan & Co. THE HEART OF RAMESES II. Mr. Berthelot has announced to the members of the Academy of Science of Paris that a notice had been received from Professor Lortet in which he gave a description of the heart of Raineses II. This was discovered during the recent excavations of the hypogeums of the Egyptian kings of the early dynasties. Its well-preserved state enabled Professor Lortet to make a detailed study. Professor Bouchard remarked that this preservation was nothing extraordinary as bodies had been discovered beneath sand at. a depth of 240 ft., belonging to a period of civilisation considerably anterior to that of Ramoses II., and in these remains it had been possible to study the fibres of the eye and the muscular tissues. HOW MARRIAGES HAPPEN. Theoretically, a man “chooses a girl from all •he world” because he loves her. Practically, 'he modern, listless man marries the girl he is unable to get away from.—"The World and His Wife.”

div.head: INDEPENDENT ORDER OF GOOD TEMPLARS
div.p: MEETING IN ALEXANDRIA. On Saturday evening last an important session of Blue Cap Pride Lodge, M. 107, was held in the Sailors and Soldiers’ Institute, Alexandria. There was a good attendance of members. The session was an open one and was availed of by many friends of temperance, who contributed to the evening’s programme. Bro. R. Ireland, C. T., presided. The Chief Templar spoke at some length on the temperance question, and urged on members the desirability of remaining faithful to their obligation and true to their noble order. The Lodge Deputy also spoke at some length during the course of which he said he was proud to say their membership was increasing, and be had every confidence it would farther increase. What was required were members of the proper stamp who would show by their conduct that they are a credit to themselves and the order to which they belong. He continued:—“It has been suggested to open a sleeping lodge for the benefit of the Alexandria garrison, viz. 'The White Nile.’ The suggestion has' my approval. A station lodge established at this home would be an inestimable boon to maty. A lodge properly officered with an educational programme having on its agenda essayd, debates, readings, recitations, & would go a long way to bring thinking men to their proper sphere. We intend to accomplish this daring the next month.” An interesting address was delivered by an Egyptian friend, and Bro. Miles also said a few words on temperance reform. An excellent programme was gone through to which the following oontributed : — Lce.- Corps Ireland and Gjrvine, B.mdardiers Smith and Webb, R.G. A., Gunners Bowler and Miles, R.G.A. and Ptes. Miller and Sutton. The various selections on the gramaphone were highly appreciated, and a vote of thanks i was conveyed to Lee. Curp. Craig Hr same. The disposal of routine business closed an enjoyable session.

div.head: ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY QUESTION
div.p: Some dissatisfaction is, it is stated, being felt at the delay in the settlement of the Ethiopian Railway question, which is very prejudicial to the interests of an important undertaking in which a large amount of English capital is involved. It will be remembered that the French State supported the company by granting, in 1902, a subsidy of £1,000,000 for the construction of the first section of the line, which starts at Djibouti. There is no question now of increasing the allowance, bat rather that the French Government should insist on the execution of the treaty passed with the Negns, according to which the railway company was to collect a special tax of 10 per cent, ad valorem on the merchandise traffic between Abyssinia and the Red Sea. If this treaty had been conscientiously repeated, not only would a dividend on the capital sunk in the venture have been possible, but the means would have been available for the building of the second section of the line to Addis Abeba. At the same time, the unexplained attitude of Colonel Sir John Harrington is widely commented upon in Franco-English financial circle. The French Government is again being urged to take immediate steps in the matter, as a freshly constituted banking syndicate—to which the new Bank of Abyssinia is said to be no stranger— is reported to be working against the present holders of the concession.

div.head: A COMPANION OF LIVINGSTONE
div.p: The death occurred last week of Mr. John Reid, the second last white man who travelled with Dr. Livingstone in his African exploring journeys. Mr. Reid, who was 74 years of age, was with Livingstone during part of his second journey, going out as a carpenter on the same boat as Mrs. Livingstone and Mr. James Stewart in order to fit together a Lake Nyassa steamer which was taken out in parts. He was away three years, and came home with the explorer. He went out again with the Livingstone search expedition, under Young and Faulkner, and on his return, finding that there was a strike at home, which rendered it difficult for him to obtain work, he accepted an engagement which took him to Peru for three years. He had many exceedingly interesting reminiscences of the famous traveller, of Mrs. Livingstone, of Dr. Stewart, of Love- dale, and of Sir John Kirk—the latter now the only white survivor of Livingstone’s travels. Mr. Reid had a good knowledge of (he management of vessels, and was on this account of great value to the explorer. He shared many of his hardships, and was sometimes ab long as nine months without seeing another white face. Of Dr. Livingstone he had the sincerest admiration, and when the news of his death came to England he said emphatically that “the natives of Africa never did it.”

div.head: STRANDING OF THE DONEGAL
RESULT OF COURT-MARTIAL
div.p: The grounding of the orniser Donegal, after passing through the Suez Canal on her way to China, on March 1, was the subject of an inquiry by a court martial on the battleship Empress of India at Devonport last week. Captain William J. Grogan, Navigating- Lieutenant L. T. Jones, Lieutenant C. R Hemans, and Sub-Lieutenant H. W. Best of the Donegal pleaded not guilty to negligently or by default stranding or hazarding their ship. Captain Grogan in a letter to the Admiralty stated that he saw the correct course, “S. 35'K,” marked off on the chart, and then inspected the physical drill. Lieutenant Jones brought down the card to him with the coarse marked "S. 25 E.” He signed the card, not noticing the electrical error. Sub-Lieutenant Best steadied the ship on the course “S. 25 B.,” and reported having done so to Lieutenant Jones, bat he did not report that this bearing would place the vessel at 5.21 p.m. 1.17 miles from Rhas el Gbarib. Lieutenant Hemans relieved at 6 p.m., and sent the card to Lieutenant Jones. The latter had just noted that the ship was too near to the land and was altering the course when she struck. Captain Grogan stated that from Wednesday he would be superseded in command of the Donegal by order of the Admiralty, and public notice of this punishment had been given prior to his trial by court-martial. He accepted fall responsibility as captain for the whole occurrence. The court sentenced Captain Grogan to be severely reprimanded, Lieutenant Jones to lose a year’s seniority and to be dismissed his ship, Lieutenant Hemans to be reprimanded, and Sub-Lieutenant Best to be severely reprimanded. NORTH GERMAN LLOYD. The North German Lloyd last year landed more passengers at New York than any other company. The total was 177,871, as against 139,972 for the, Hamburg-American Line, 98,419 for the Canard, and 91,435 for the White Star. It is also noticeable that the ' cabin passengers conveyed by the N. D. L. | amounted to 42,817, or almost doable that of I the Hamburg-American Line, which took 23,109 while the Canard took 21,032 and the White Star 27,946. N COTTON TRADE IN MARCH. The Board cf Trade returns of the exports of cotton yarn and manufactures and the imports and exports of raw material for March are to hand. From these we gather that daring that month Egypt imported cotton yarn to the extent of 240,100 lbs., as compared with 814,800 lbs. in the same month last year, and 252,700 lbs. in 1904. Germany and Holland were the largest importers with 3,532,300 and 3,412,100 lbs. respectively, Italy taking the smallest quantity, viz. 1,600 lbs. With regard to imports of cotton manufactures, Egypt last month received 19,131,100 yards, as against 24,248,800 yards in March, 1905, and 15,806,400 yards in 1904. Thus it will be seen that March, 1905, was an abnormal month in the matter of the imports of both these articles. Last month, however, the exports of cotton from Egypt exceeded both those of both previous years, the figures being 445,327 owts., as compared with 403,497 owts. in 1905, and 273,624 owts. in 1904. OPERATIONS IN EGYPTIAN MINES. Mr. C. J. Alford has furnished the following summary of the month’s operations: Atallah Mine (Central Egypt Company), March 96— Main shaft down 180 ft; granite slightly decomposed. Semna Mine (Fatira Company), March 24—Main shaft (late No. 9), first level east, 82 ft.; last 13 ft. vein averaged 66 in. wide and 30 5 dwt. gold per ton. First level west, 32 ft.; last 15 ft. vein averaged 44 in wide and 17 dwt gold per ton. In face, vein is 36 in wide with 30 dwt. gold per ton. No. 8 Shaft, first level east, 100 ft. ; vein 24 in. wide, 14-5 dwt gold per ton. First level west, 48 ft; vein 16 in. wide, 5-5 dwt. gold per ton. GUM ARABIC. div.head: EGYPT A "SAFE DEPOSIT"
div.p: At one time favourite speculative counters in all the European Stock Markets, Egyptian Unified bonds have, says a writer in the “Financier,” long passed into the strictly investment and humdrum category. “From a cosmopolitan Tom Tiddler's ground the Land of the Pharaohs has, likewise, under the fostering care of the British roarer, become a veritable safe-deposit, the financial position revesding unparalleled prosperity. The Budget shows that in the conne of last year no less than £4,791,460 of the Public Debt was redeemed, leaving a total of £96,483,880 outstanding at December 81«t. The 8nrplns amounted, after liberal appropriations for reproductive works, to ££.2,688,524, and the different reserve funds to£K9,050,000. The Four per Cent. Unified bonds have been slowly creeping up since I drew attention to them some months ago, and at their present price of 106J give a modest 3| per cent. The security is, however, irreproachable, and to those of my readers fond of an innocent flatter on ’heads I win, tails I don’t lose’ lines I would recommend a purchase in anticipation of the May coupon.”' The same writer, in referring to the large basinets done in the Shares of Egyptian Options daring the past few days, mentions that the company possesses mineral concessions covering as area of 12/ 00 square miles, upon which its prospectois are at work under the direction of Mr Merton, of Merton's Reward fame. According to market rumonr, some important discoveries have been made, and, as the issued capital is only £20,000, any definite news of gold discoveries should lead to a big rise in the price of the shares. Indeed, £10 is talked of as a possible figure by some sanguine people. The company is also interested in robber propositions, particularly the Abyssinian concession recently granted by King Menelik. The shares certainly look worth picking up round about present prices. THE STEAM ENGINE IN ANCIENT EGYPT. Mr. G. Gerald Stoney, in a recent lecture at Carpenters’ Hall, London, on “Steam Turbines,” said it was among the relics of ancient Egyptian civilisation, 20 centuries ago, that the first records of the steam engine were found. In Alexandria, the home of Buclid, Hero wrote his “Spiritnalia sen Pneumatics,” wherein he described two machines of special interest. The one utilised the expansive force of air in a closed vessel heated externally, the pnenmatic force being applied upon the surface of water in other vessels, and the hydranlic force utilised for opening the doors of Grecian temples, and working other pseudo-magic contrivances. The other was a veritable steam turbine engine, snoh, in principle, as they were disonssing that night. It seemed doubtfnl whether this machine was ever more than a toy, or whether it was used by the Greek priests for producing motion of apparatus in their temples. Bat from the experience of the last 20 years, it appeared that with some improvement in design and constraction it could have been applied to perform useful work, and might have claimed a place among steam engines even up to the middle of the last century.
